10

JPMorgan executive is first casualty of major blunder

In the wake of the bank’s $2 billion loss, JP Morgan Chase CIO Ina Drew, the person responsible for trading strategy, will retire, the bank said. (AP, 12:59 p.m.)
  • Warren allies call on Brown to release JPMorgan ties

Obama campaign attacks Romney's record as Bain Capital executive

The Obama campaign unleashed its first ad attacking Romney’s record as an executive, painting him as a callous “vampire” and “job destroyer." (Globe, 1:44 p.m.)

Court won't hear suit against FBI by alleged Bulger victim's relatives

The US Supreme Court has refused to resurrect a lawsuit filed against the FBI by the family of an alleged victim of James "Whitey" Bulger. (Globe, 2 p.m.)
Past coverage of 'Whitey' Bulger

Dorchester man charged with running prostitution ring out of his home

Leroy Lockett, 59, is expected back in court today to face a felony charge of making income from being a pimp, according to Suffolk County prosecutors. (Globe, 1:22 p.m.)

Opinion | Dr. Donald M. Berwick

In health care, cheaper can be better

Can the state's health care be universal, excellent, and far less expensive? Absolutely, writes the former head of the federal Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services.

County jails' HIV programs cut

The state has eliminated more than $1 million for HIV testing and education in county jails, alarming sheriffs who fear the cuts threaten the health of inmates.

Helping survivors of military sexual trauma

The Department of Veterans Affairs calls military sexual trauma "an epidemic," bringing a need for specialized care.

E-retailer aims to up city's hip factor

Karmaloop, an online seller of so-called streetwear, is on a $200,000 mission to make Boston as hip as the clothing it sells.
Magazine

An autistic son leaves the nest

It’s a joy to see him out on his own, but for a mom whose mission has been to get him what he needs, a little sad too.
Dan Shaughnessy

Celtics give their all, Sox strike out

Fans are loving the gritty, hard-working Celtics this postseason, while the moody, underachieving Sox are generating enmity.

More college presidents hail from outside academia

Twenty percent of college presidents in the US come from nontraditional or business backgrounds, up from 13 percent six years ago.

MD Mama

What being 'Mom enough' means

I don't encourage attachment parenting--or any kind of parenting, for that matter. My job, as I see it, is to help families find their way, Dr. Claire writes.

Politics

Poll: Obama’s gay marriage stance aligns with youth, women

President Obama’s endorsement of legal same-sex marriage is likely to resonate with young voters and women, two blocs where Obama is already strong, a new Gallup poll indicates.

Business

The best business movies

Good business movies—with the exception of those shown in the conference room— feature the greed, tragedy, and revenge of a Shakespearean play, plus a dose of romance and triumph. What’s not to like?
